I don't know what is going to happen," one woman said.</p><p>The fire in hills near the central city of Loule, some 250 kilometres south of Lisbon, has blackened thousands of hectares of scrub and farmland.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5W9D-S681-F0J6-J42C-00000-00Dedication to career recognised2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisDedication to career recognisedNatalie Croxon

A career of 42 years with Forest Fire Management Victoria has seen Heathcote's Pat McCarthy awarded the Australian Fire Service Medal. Mr McCarthy began his career in Heathcote in 1976 and now supervises both the Heathcote and Rushworth depots as a forest fire management officer. Mr McCarthy is described as a highly experienced and knowledgeable fire ground leader who is held in high regard by his colleagues and members of the wider community, including other emergency services.

urn:contentItem:485Y-FH30-015H-D4SB-00000-00<published>2003-03-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire avoidable -- group</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>FIONA ADOLPH</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CONSERVATION groups say a fire that this week burnt out a forest about 80 times the size of Kings Park should never have happened.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The blaze blackened 32,000ha of the proposed Walpole Wilderness Area after flaring up last Sunday.</p><p>It was WA's biggest forest fire in more than 30 years.</p><p> WA Forest Alliance spokesman Peter Robertson said the Department of Conservation and Land Management's "questionable management" of the blaze had contributed to the loss. He called for an independent inquiry into the blaze.</p><p> The fire started more than a month ago after a lightning strike.</p><p> Mr Robertson said about a quarter of the wilderness area had been lost to fires since spring.</p><p> He said the department, as part of its burn-off strategy, firebombed a 6000ha block of the forest, causing spot fires that burnt out of control.</p><p> The department said it would welcome an inquiry and would brief conservation groups once mopping up was completed. Firefighters' safety had been paramount, it said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:53WN-2K31-F0JP-W3Y9-00000-00Arson possible in forest fire2011-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 7Arson possible in forest fire

FORESTRY Tasmania says a 10ha plantation fire burning near Railton in the North-West appears to have been deliberately lit.

The Tasmania Fire Service and Forestry Tasmania were alerted to the blaze about 5.5km north of the township at 5pm on Sunday.

Fire crews conducted back-burning operations and contained the fire inside the coupe's boundary track, a Forestry Tasmania spokesman said yesterday.

Smoke was reportedly visible in the Railton and Sheffield area but it was not expected to affect residents, the spokesman said.

Firefighters were still at the scene last night with the cause not yet confirmed.

Pg. 17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire kills four</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Darrell Giles</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOUR firefighters were killed and six others injured battling a forest fire at Winthrop, about 150km east of Seattle.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze, believed to have been started by an unattended campfire, exploded out of control and engulfed firefighters, in the nation's deadliest wildfire since 1994.</p><p>Rising temperatures helped fuel the out-of-control fire yesterday.</p><p>Six hundred extra firefighters were flown into the area in an attempt to stop the blaze.</p><p>US Forest Service officials said a campfire was suspected as the cause.</p><p> "This is a great tragedy and loss that is felt by all firefighters and agency employees everywhere," said Sonny O'Neal, supervisor of the Okanogan and Wenatchee national forests.</p><p>"Firefighters are a family, and any time a firefighter is killed, grief is felt by all."</p><p> Crews withdrew from the area last night and fire officials said they would not be sent back until it was safe.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4RHN-H4H0-TXDB-G02P-00000-00Kuitpo forest fire contained2008-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisKuitpo forest fire contained

South Australia's Country Fire Service (CFS) says a fire south of Adelaide has been contained.

It was reported before 11:00am ACDT burning near Kuitpo Forest around Peters Creek and Brookman Roads.

About 70 fire fighters and two water bombers are still putting out the fire.

No property has been damaged at this stage.

urn:contentItem:5XYC-K3Y1-JC0X-K12X-00000-00<published>2020-01-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Luke Costin<br/>   SYDNEY, Jan 10 AAP - Snowmaking machines are being used to help battle fires in the alpine region with a wind change potentially placing ski resorts under threat.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   NSW's Thredbo Resort, which is among the many ski fields closed until further notice due to the fires, has been running its snowmaking machines non-stop for days to wet the ground, Aneeki Ski Lodge owner Stephen Turner said.<br/>   "It stops the ember attack," he told AAP on Friday.<br/>   "At 1800m, we're above the treeline so ... we can protect the ski assets."<br/>   The potential for disaster is clear after buildings at Selwyn Snow Resort were severely damaged when the Dunns Road fire hit the Kosciuszko National Park ski destination last weekend.<br/>   Mr Turner said he was most concerned about a southerly wind change, recorded at 90 kilometres at Albury, that could fan a 3600-hectare blaze south of Thredbo.<br/>   Embers could particularly affect the golf course and elevated lodges, he said.<br/>   "It'll be like a blowtorch," he said.<br/>   "If it gets into the ski resort ... It can burn around the village and keep going.<br/>   "There's no point having a ski resort with no lifts, lodges or other infrastructure."<br/>   Aircraft was used to dump fire retardant on a fire near Charlotte Pass on Friday.<br/>   Snowmaking lines were also primed and crews on stand-by on Victoria's Mount Buller, the mountain's resort management said on Friday.<br/>   "The main risk for the remainder of Friday and Saturday is dry lightning strikes as the weather change starts to move through the resorts from around 5pm," chief executive Mark Bennetts said in a statement.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria said they had more than 200 firefighters and a dozen aircraft operating across the Buffalo Valley.<br/>   FFMV Ovens region deputy incident controller Jarrod Hayse told reporters most of the 180km of fire perimeter was uncontained and significant impact was expected on plantations and alpine areas.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYC-K3Y1-JC0X-K12X-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="322"/><timeReceived>8:01 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. in the north of New Zealand's South Island, Radio New Zealand reported yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It said the fire had engulfed around 20 square kilometres of a forestry block of radiata pine.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> About 100 firefighters were battling the blaze, backed up by four helicopters, 12 fire engines, six water tankers and five bulldozers, local media reported.</p><section urn:contentItem:458P-9760-0197-82J3-00000-00<published>1996-06-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire threatens city </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Unrelenting winds spread a violent forest fire closer to Alaska's biggest city yesterday, officials said.</p><p>The fire, which started on Sunday, fanned out to burn 4500 hectares, consume homes and other buildings and forced the evacuation of up to 1000 people in the MatanuskaSusitna Borough north of Anchorage, State officials said.</p><p> As the fire spread south toward Anchorage 48km away, the city of 225,000 people was protected by a long, narrow bay, although a curtain of grey smoke was visible in the northern sky.</p><p> As for homes destroyed, "We know it's probably in the hundreds. We just haven't had the personnel to count them," said firefighting commander Dave Liebersbach.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4MJG-WJ90-TXDB-G2H2-00000-00Forest fire threatens homes in eastern Tasmania2006-12-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisForest fire threatens homes in eastern Tasmania

Firefighters on Tasmania's east coast are battling extreme winds as they work to protect properties from a dry forest fire.

Winds of up to 110 kilometres per hour have grounded firefighting aircraft and are fanning a fire north of St Marys and east of German Town.

The fire has already claimed a house, a caravan and several cars.

It is expected to cross St Marys Pass at some stage this afternoon.

Communications officer Danny Reid says St Marys Pass may be closed and people are being asked to defer non-essential travel to the area.

"There'll certainly be properties that are under threat this afternoon," he said.

"Our crews will be in property protection mode while those windy conditions are continuing up there and while the fire is moving along so actively."

Firefighters working on the Bream Creek fire say their containment plans are progressing but they are concerned about the possibility of windy conditions this afternoon.

urn:contentItem:5DBT-8NK1-F031-X3BY-00000-00Dry conditions heighten forest fire threat2014-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisDry conditions heighten forest fire threat

The Country Fire Service says dry conditions have increased the risk of grass and forestry fires this summer.

The fire danger season is likely to start in South Australia's lower and upper south-east next month but exact dates are yet to be confirmed.

An early start to the season has been declared for the Flinders, Eastern Eyre Peninsula, mid-north and west coast districts.

CFS Region 5 commander John Probert said people need to be prepared before the fire danger season started.

"It's getting too late when you see the flames at your doorstep to leave then," he said.

"People need to make sure that they have a practised and written bushfire action plan in place and something that they talk their way through with their kids and they know well ahead of a catastrophic day exactly what they will do should a fire occur.

"The forests are very dry and we are concerned about [the] soil dryness index etcetera which means the potential for forests fires is bad, but fast-running grassfires are always a problem for us and this year is no different to any other and if we get fires in grassland over the summer they're going to move very, very quickly and people need to be aware of that."

urn:contentItem:5XXS-2631-DYG0-9461-00000-00<published>2020-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - A father-of-two confirmed as having lost his life fighting Victoria's bushfires, has become the state's third fatality of the crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Forest Fires Management worker Matt Kavanagh was killed when he and a colleague were involved in a crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway while on duty on January 3.<br/>   The 43-year-old died at the scene, while his colleague was taken to hospital and has since been released.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville confirmed on Wednesday his death was related to the bushfires, following a police investigation.<br/>   "Matt was a dedicated and respected member of Forest Fire Management Victoria for around 10 years and was on duty as a part of our fire response on the day," she told reporters.<br/>   "He is being remembered for his friendly and welcoming nature, his passion for the environment and nature and his love of fly fishing."<br/>   Mr Kavanagh is survived by his wife Jude and two children.<br/>   Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said Mr Kavanagh had worked in many roles at the organisation including as a firefighter, a roads management officer and most recently in fire prevention.<br/>   On the morning of the accident, he hadextinguished seven unattended campfires.<br/>   "He was doing critically important work stopping new fires in the environment and we have 2800 people doing that every day right across the state," Mr Hardman said.<br/>   "It's a devastating loss for everybody in the sector but for those people who knew Matt it's going to take a long time - I can't imagine what the family are going through and what Matt's colleagues are going through. It's such a very sad day."<br/>   Mick Roberts, 67, from Buchan and Maramingo Creek timber worker Fred Becker were also killed while battling bushfires this summer.<br/>   More than 400 homes have been destroyed as the fires rage across East Gippsland and the state's northeast.<br/>   More than 1.2 million hectares have been scorched in fires across the state, with 12 still burning.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XXS-2631-DYG0-9461-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-08</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="336"/><timeReceived>5:07 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XX6-KGJ1-DYG0-93SG-00000-00<published>2020-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - The cooler, wet weather that has brought relief to Victoria is creating new hazards in the bushfire-ravaged east.<br/>   More than one million hectares have burnt across Victoria, mostly in East Gippsland.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Smoke blanketing the region is adding to the difficulty of firefighting and relief efforts.<br/>   Rain has started to fall, but not across all fire-affected areas and not enough to douse the fires, and is creating new difficulties.<br/>   "It does in fact create some other challenges in a strange way we had a Forest Fire Management vehicle tip over yesterday, thankfully no one was seriously injured," Premier Daniel Andrews told 3AW on Monday.<br/>   Mr Andrews said the track the vehicle was travelling had been greasy because rain had not fallen there in such a long time.<br/>   "So it's better than it not raining but it's nowhere near enough for us to think this far event's over," he said.<br/>   There are 31 fires burning across Victoria as of Monday morning, with 18 in eastern Gippsland and six in the northeast.<br/>   The deadly fires have destroyed at least 110 properties and 220 outbuildings.<br/>   The fires have already killed Buchan man Mick Roberts and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker. Four people remain missing.<br/>   The cooler weather has allowed military helicopters to deliver supplies to isolated communities and help with evacuations, reaching 13 communities on Sunday.<br/>   They also rescued 406 people from Mallacoota and will continue to try and fly out a remaining 300 people who registered for evacuation. Navy ships brought out more than 1100 people on Saturday.<br/>   More than 3500 properties remain without power, with AusNet bringing in generators when possible and restoring the network when it is safe to do so.<br/>   Emergency warnings are in place for bushfire-threatened East Gippsland communities at Cann Valley and in the Drummer and Merremingger state forests.<br/>   Light rain fell across Victoria on Sunday, but authorities urged people to remain vigilant.<br/>   The Victorian government has announced a fund to support Victorian bushfire survivors,contributing $2 million.<br/>   The national fire disaster has shocked Australians and prompted generous donations from all corners of the country.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XX6-KGJ1-DYG0-93SG-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="371"/><timeReceived>9:07 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XXS-39R1-DYG0-946N-00000-00<published>2020-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Corrects first name to "Mat"<br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - A father-of-two confirmed as having lost his life fighting Victoria's bushfires, has become the state's third fatality of the crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Forest Fires Management worker Mat Kavanagh was killed when he and a colleague were involved in a crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway while on duty on January 3.<br/>   The 43-year-old died at the scene, while his colleague was taken to hospital and has since been released.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville confirmed on Wednesday his death was related to the bushfires, following a police investigation.<br/>   "Mat was a dedicated and respected member of Forest Fire Management Victoria for around 10 years and was on duty as a part of our fire response on the day," she told reporters.<br/>   "He is being remembered for his friendly and welcoming nature, his passion for the environment and nature and his love of fly fishing."<br/>   Mr Kavanagh is survived by his wife Jude and two children.<br/>   Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said Mr Kavanagh had worked in many roles at the organisation including as a firefighter, a roads management officer and most recently in fire prevention.<br/>   On the morning of the accident, he hadextinguished seven unattended campfires.<br/>   "He was doing critically important work stopping new fires in the environment and we have 2800 people doing that every day right across the state," Mr Hardman said.<br/>   "It's a devastating loss for everybody in the sector but for those people who knew Mat it's going to take a long time - I can't imagine what the family are going through and what Mat's colleagues are going through. It's such a very sad day."<br/>   Mick Roberts, 67, from Buchan and Maramingo Creek timber worker Fred Becker were also killed while battling bushfires this summer.<br/>   More than 400 homes have been destroyed as the fires rage across East Gippsland and the state's northeast.<br/>   More than 1.2 million hectares have been scorched in fires across the state, with 12 still burning.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XXS-39R1-DYG0-946N-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-08</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="340"/><timeReceived>6:03 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5WTC-4M91-JD3N-51WX-00000-00Call goes out for firefighters2019-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Call goes out for firefightersOLIVIA REED

FOREST Fire Management is recruiting 73 project firefighters to conduct bushfire prevention work in the Barwon South West region.

Assistant chief fire officer Andrew Morrow said FFM was seeking men and women to join the team for the summer season.

Mr Morrow said project firefighters were on the frontline fighting bushfires, -conducting planned burns and undertaking roadside -vegetation and fire trail -maintenance.

He said FFM would have more than 1000 frontline forest firefighters ready for the new season, with 600 PFFs and 340 permanent forest fire operations officers.

Mr Morrow said there were 40 positions available in the far southwest district and 33 in the Otway district.

"We have also identified a number of these positions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people," he said.

Employment is full-time for a period of up to 26 weeks, generally between November and April.

Applications for project firefighters are open until Sunday, August 25.For details and to apply, visit jobs.careers.vic.gov.au/pff or call 136 186.

urn:contentItem:57Y4-66G1-F031-X44H-00000-00Police suspect arson in tree-sit forest fire2013-03-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisPolice suspect arson in tree-sit forest fire

Tasmanian police are treating a bushfire in a southern forest at the centre of an anti-logging protest as arson.

Environmentalist Miranda Gibson ended her tree-sit in the Tyenna Valley last Thursday, two days after the fire broke out.

She had lived on a platform for 449 days in a campaign to end logging in native forests, attracting global attention.

Forestry Tasmania has found the fire was deliberately lit and police are treating it as an arson case.

They are appealing for anyone who may have witnessed suspicious activity in the vicinity of Muellers or Styx Roads last Tuesday afternoon to contact them.

urn:contentItem:7XSB-VBS1-2RYX-101V-00000-00Forest fire under control2010-02-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 25Forest fire under control

FIRE crews have contained a 6450-hectare bushfire at Wayatinah that began burning 12 days ago and threatened the town of Ouse and surrounding properties.

The Tasmania Fire Service said crews were able to make progress on the Wayatinah fire because of good weather conditions yesterday.

The firefighting operation will continue today.

TFS incident controller Gerald Crawford said there was little fire activity on the eastern side of the fire between the River Derwent and the Lyell Highway and this area would continue to be patrolled by air.

Crews, including remote area firefighters from the TFS and Parks and Wildlife, concentrated on the Heals Spur and Mt Thunderbolt sections of the fire yesterday.

Roads closed are Long Spur Rd (B Station Rd) and Florentine Rd.

urn:contentItem:5X98-3111-F0J6-J3XS-00000-00Controlled burns planned for Heathcote2019-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 3Controlled burns planned for Heathcote

Forest Fire Management and the Country Fire Authority will be conducting a planned burn in Heathcote from Monday.

The fuel reduction burn will take place on the Dargile Track in the Heathcote-Graytown National Park, about six kilometres north of Heathcote.

The 172-hectare burn will be completed between Monday, October 14 and Wednesday, October 16 if weather permits.

There may be smoke visible from Heathcote, Costerfield, Mount Camel, and Redcastle until Friday, October 18.

Read more: Forest Fire Management, Country Fire Authority prepare for the upcoming fire season

The management authority has advised some roads may be hazardous due to low viability from smoke.

There may also be signs in place to slow down.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites close to the planned burn may also be restricted.

The management authority has encouraged residents in Heathcote and surrounding towns to stay informed about the controlled burn at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:56W2-9721-JCM0-64SJ-00000-00Strong winds to fan forest fire2012-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisStrong winds to fan forest fire

Fire fighters have now contained a blaze that's burning in a pine plantation north-west of Casino.

Michael Brett, from the Rural Fire Service, says no homes are being threatened by the fire in a remote area near Sextonville.

But he says winds of up to 45 kilometres an hour are expected this afternoon.

Superintendent Brett says there could be other trouble spots hidden by the smoke.

"Based on the number of lightning strikes we had yesterday, we don't know what's actually out there and we won't know until later this afternoon," he said.

"Currently the weather conditions inhibit us putting an aircraft up, because there's so much smoke and there is a bit of an inversion layer.

"So we are a little bit concerned that potentially there is going to be significant fire activity around the Northern Rivers later this afternoon."

urn:contentItem:53VN-6HK1-JDKC-R1TF-00000-00FIREFIGHTERS RESPOND TO LARGE FOREST FIRE IN EURIMBLA STATE FOREST NEAR TURKEY BEACH2011-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisFIREFIGHTERS RESPOND TO LARGE FOREST FIRE IN EURIMBLA STATE FOREST NEAR TURKEY BEACH

BRISBANE, Qld., Sept. 22 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

Firefighters are currently at the scene of a large forest fire in the Eurimbla State Forest near Turkey Beach. The fire which has been burning for over a week is currently located south of Oakey Creek and is moving slowly in a north easterly direction towards the Danube Road near the township of Turkey Beach. An aircraft is currently conducting aerial surveillance to map the fire. Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) personnel have door knocked properties in the area to advise residents of the situation. Residents in the area are advised that this fire is causing a large amount of smoke which may continue for some time. Residents are advised to keep informed by listening to their local radio station and monitoring www.disaster.qld.gov.au. If residents believe their property becomes threatened by the fire they are advised to call Triple Zero (000) immediately. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:5W9V-PH41-JD34-V4H9-00000-00Here is why smoke will be visible from Mount Arapiles on Tuesday2019-06-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisHere is why smoke will be visible from Mount Arapiles on TuesdayAlexander Darling

Forest Fire Management Victoria is beginning a planned burn near the Centenary Park-Pines camping area at Mount Arapiles-Tooan State Park.

Tuesday's burn should be complete by 6pm, but the authority said people in surrounding areas may be affected by smoke from the 8.9-hectare burn.

"The burn objective is to use traditional owner techniques to provide conditions for the establishment of native grasses in densities at least double than present within 3 years of annual burning," the body said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

The authority did another burn at the tourist attraction in preparation for Tuesday's in April.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority expected to complete planned burn around Madex Track near Ararat in the Ararat Hills Regional Park on Sunday.

The fire was ignited on Wednesday.

"The objective of this burn is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires," A Forest Fire Management statement said.

Residents could be be affected by smoke from these planned burns and smoke might be visible from nearby localities and communities.

The location of the planned burn was listed as Map page 6259, GR: 686746.

urn:contentItem:4RY5-Y3R0-TXDB-G06D-00000-00Forest fire burning in north east2008-02-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisForest fire burning in north east

Firefighters are still battling to control a blaze near Pipers River in tasmania's north east.

It has burnt out about 225 hectares, and is being fanned by strong winds and low humidity.

The fire appears to have started in an area where Forestry Tasmania was harvesting.

40 firefighters, 11 tankers, five bulldozers and a helicopter are being used to fight it.

urn:contentItem:5B73-KT61-JCM0-611H-00000-00Fears Barmah Forest fire may flare up in wind change2014-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisFears Barmah Forest fire may flare up in wind change

Authorities are keeping a close eye on a bushfire in the Barmah Forest, near Nathalia, in northern Victoria.

The 39-hectare blaze started late yesterday in Hughes Lane at Yielima and it took 100 firefighters until just after midnight to contain it.

There are concerns the fire could flare up after a strong southerly wind change.

The cause of the fire is under investigation.

CFA incident controller, Phil Hawkey, says it is expected to take some time to extinguish.

"There's a number of large older trees that are hollow trees that are burning," he said.

"These trees are creating issues with us because they're spreading embers and so forth and they're going to continue burning through the day and possibly for the next few days."

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - The Victorian bushfire death toll has risen to four after a firefighter died battling a blaze in the state's alpine region.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter from Parks Victoria was killed while battling a blaze in the Omeo area on Saturday, Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed.<br/>   "Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said in a statement.<br/>   ?The safety and wellbeing of our people is our highest priority.?<br/>   The firefighter's death will be investigated by Victoria Police, who will prepare a report for the coroner.<br/>   It comes after another Forest Fires Management worker Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed in the fires at East Gippsland on New Year's Day.<br/>   While bushfireconditions have eased, Mr Crisp warned there was a "long way to go" before the state's fire season was over.<br/>   "It is great to have some respite now, so we can reset and refocus in terms of our operational activities and what we can do to support community, but we will have more hot weather," he told reporters on Saturday.<br/>   "We are planning through until the end of March."<br/>   Cooler temperatures and rainfall eased conditions on Saturday after Friday's strong southwesterly whipped up fires in the alpine and East Gippsland regions.<br/>   While an emergency warning remains in place for a fire near Mount Hotham, the state of disaster declared for the regions has ended.<br/>   Milder conditions are forecast for the next week to 10 days, meaning attention can turn to getting the upper hand on the more than 20 fires still burning.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said relieving exhausted emergency services workers was also a priority.<br/>   "People are very fatigued, that is the case with communities but also the case with our emergency service personnel, they are very exhausted and we need to be able to rotate in and out people," she told reporters on Saturday.<br/>   "We have got a chance to do that whilst we are also still doing a lot of the planning, a lot of the work that we can do to try and minimise the future impact of these fires."<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - The Victorian bushfire death toll has risen to four after a firefighter died battling a blaze in the state's alpine region.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter from Parks Victoria was killed while battling a blaze in the Omeo area on Saturday, Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed.<br/>   "Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said in a statement.<br/>   ?The safety and wellbeing of our people is our highest priority.?<br/>   The firefighter's death will be investigated by Victoria Police, who will prepare a report for the coroner.<br/>   It comes after another Forest Fires Management worker Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed in the fires at East Gippsland on New Year's Day.<br/>   While bushfireconditions have eased, Mr Crisp warned there was a "long way to go" before the state's fire season was over.<br/>   "It is great to have some respite now, so we can reset and refocus in terms of our operational activities and what we can do to support community, but we will have more hot weather," he told reporters on Saturday.<br/>   "We are planning through until the end of March."<br/>   Cooler temperatures and rainfall eased conditions on Saturday after Friday's strong southwesterly whipped up fires in the alpine and East Gippsland regions.<br/>   While an emergency warning remains in place for a fire near Mount Hotham, the state of disaster declared for the regions has ended.<br/>   Milder conditions are forecast for the next week to 10 days, meaning attention can turn to getting the upper hand on the more than 20 fires still burning.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said relieving exhausted emergency services workers was also a priority.<br/>   "People are very fatigued, that is the case with communities but also the case with our emergency service personnel, they are very exhausted and we need to be able to rotate in and out people," she told reporters on Saturday.<br/>   "We have got a chance to do that whilst we are also still doing a lot of the planning, a lot of the work that we can do to try and minimise the future impact of these fires."<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SP8-3H41-JD3N-51P8-00000-00Firewood season ends2018-06-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 25Firewood season ends

THE autumn firewood collection season will close across the Barwon South West region today.Forest Fire Management Victoria acting regional manager Tim Gazzard said: "It will be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the spring firewood collection season". He said the public can start collecting firewood again from designated areas on September 1 pending suitable conditions. Forest Fire Management Victoria staff will patrol forests and reserves to ensure people are not breaking the law.

urn:contentItem:4MDH-K8S0-TXCG-J28P-00000-00Massive forest2006-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisPg. 2Massive forestfire in Jimboomba

THOUSANDS of residents as far south as Jimboomba and north to Loganholme woke to a thick blanket of grey smoke from a massive fire in a pine forest near Logan Village on Wednesday.

The fire, believed to be deliberately lit, destroyed about 770ha in part of the old Hancock's Pine Forest earmarked for the residential estate Yarrabilba.

Thick smoke from the blaze also stopped traffic on Waterford-Tamborine Rd for short periods on Tuesday evening when visibility dropped to zero.

No damage to homes and no injuries were reported by late last night when the evacuated residents were allowed to return home.- APEND OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>-KEYS- -LIB- -SECT- NEWS</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5V4K-1651-F0J6-J0TS-00000-00Five units bring Glen Park fire under control2019-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisFive units bring Glen Park fire under control

Five CFA and forest fire management units have brought a blaze in the Creswick State Forest at Glen Park under control.

The grass fire, reported shortly before 3pm, was burning on Code's Forest Road near Wallaby Track to the west of White Swan Reservoir and was travelling in a Northerly direction.

CFA units from Invermay and Glen Park were first on scene and were joined shortly after by three units from the State Government's Forest Fire Management service to contain the fire.

The CFA issued the information alert at 3.41 and the blaze was brought under control a short time later after it had burnt out about half a hectare.

The warning noted that while the fire did not threaten property, smoke from the blaze could affect people's health.

Fire investigators will now look at the area to discern a cause of the fire.

urn:contentItem:4VBV-GM20-TXX1-F05N-00000-00KUITPO FOREST FIRE Police seek help2009-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15KUITPO FOREST FIRE Police seek help

POLICE need information to find the person who lit a scrub fire at Kuitpo Forest on Saturday.

The fire started about 1pm and destroyed scrub adjoining farming land off Dashwood Gully Rd, Kangarilla.

In a separate incident yesterday morning, police arrested an Allenby Gardens boy, 15, and charged him with lighting a fire in the open in the fire danger season.

Police allegedly caught the teenager lighting a scrub fire about 1.20am on Tanahmerah Rd, Carey Gully. He has been bailed to appear in the Mt Barker Youth Court on April 29.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire sparks state of emergency</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Buenos Aires PRESIDENT Carlos Menem yesterday declared a state of emergency in the southern city of Bariloche and the surrounding area as a raging forest fire advanced through the Andean hills.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Firefighters were unable to contain the fire, which has consumed a hotel, houses and thousands of hectares of forest since starting more than a week ago.</p><p>Crews were awaiting the arrival yesterday of two water planes offered by the Chilean Government, other firefighting equipment and Argentine soldiers to mount a reinforced attack against the fire.</p><p>The size of the disaster, which has destroyed vast swathes of virgin forest and threatens populated areas around Bariloche, led Menem to take the matter out of the hands of Environment Secretary Maria Julia Alsogaray.</p><p>Alsogaray, the focus of criticism from environmental groups and political leaders for her management in the crisis, had assured the President last Thursday that the blaze was contained.</p><p>AFP</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5XTM-RM91-JD34-V4NH-00000-00Safety at camp fires2019-12-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisSafety at camp fires

Central Victorian campers are being reminded to stay alert when it comes to campfire safety. There have been 75 bushfires in the region since July 1, 2019, with 27 of those fires caused by campfire negligence. Forest Fire Management Victoria regional manager Paul Bates said campers should never leave a campfire unattended. Campfires must not be ignited on total fire ban days. More information about campfire safety can be found at ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:4N7B-FT10-TX5J-C2HT-00000-00Boys start huge forest fire2007-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 42

MATP

Boys start huge forest fire

BEIJING: Six schoolboys playing with lighters started a fire that engulfed a forest in south-west China and took 10,000 firefighters two days to put out, state media reported yesterday.

The fire was started on Friday morning and spread over 233 hectares in Yunnan Province.

The six boys blamed for the blaze were fifth-graders at a local primary school in Dali, a popular tourist city in an area inhabited by the Bai ethnic minority. The boys ran away when they saw the fire spread, and there were no casualties from the blaze, the media outlet Xinhua said.

It was not clear how the boys were identified.

urn:contentItem:53M0-RR31-F031-X13X-00000-00Burns meeting fails to quell forest fire fears2011-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisBurns meeting fails to quell forest fire fears

Environmentalists say a meeting with authorities has failed to resolve concerns central Victoria's box ironbark forests will not be protected from fuel reduction burns.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) has more than doubled its burn target for the Murray Goldfields district this season.

The Central Victorian Combined Environment Network's Vanessa Richardson says she was very disappointed by the meeting with the DSE last Friday.

"We weren't satisfied with the meeting at all," she said.

"We spent an hour and a half trying to reach some positive outcomes just so that we can be sure ... [on] environment grounds that some of the areas of our national park will be protected from the fuel reduction burns.

"At this stage they have no protection."

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V4MH-00000-00Total fire ban declared in Victoria for Saturday2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisTotal fire ban declared in Victoria for SaturdayRochelle Kirkham

A total fire ban has been declared for the whole of Victoria on Saturday, with forecast hot and windy weather raising the fire danger rating in the Ballarat region to severe.

State parks and forests across the Grampians region will remain open, but Forest Fire Management Victoria is reminding campers it is illegal to light a campfire on a total fire ban day.

Assistant chief fire officer Grampians region Peter Kambouris said Forest Fire Management Victoria crews extinguished a number of unattended campfires during the Christmas and New Year period.

"Under the right conditions, any one of these campfires could have become a bushfire and threatened lives, property and the environment," Mr Kambouris said.

READ MORE ABOUT CAMPFIRE SAFETY:

"Historically in the Grampians region, we've had far too many bushfires caused by campfire negligence and this is placing the community, firefighters and the environment at risk."

Escaped campfires cause around 10% of bushfires, according to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Barbecues in parks can also not be lit on a total fire ban day.

CFA advises people living in areas at risk of fire to activate their bush fire plan.

urn:contentItem:4PD5-TR80-TX52-T4TP-00000-00Mt Fox forest fire plan2007-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Mt Fox forest fire plan

A BURNOUT has been planned for Mt Fox State Forest, as part of the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service's annual hazard reduction program for parks and forests.

The burn is planned for Tuesday August 14, starting about 11am if weather conditions are favourable. Smoke may be seen in the Watts Rd, Lagoon Creek Rd and Oak Hills Rd section of Mt Fox, as a result of the burn.

The aim of the project is to control lantana, reduce the volume of forest fuels and create a mosaic of burnt and unburnt areas within the park.

It is hoped the burn will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires in the summer months and provide conditions for forest regeneration.

urn:contentItem:4P0W-WTV0-TXN5-V27B-00000-00Arrest over forest fire2002-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Arrest over forest fire

A Sydney man has been arrested and charged with lighting a fire in the Southern Highlands yesterday.

The 47-year-old man from Narrabeen was allegedly seen sitting beside a fire in the undergrowth of Penrose State Forest, 1km off the Hume Highway at Sutton Forest. Penrose Bushfire Brigade extinguished the blaze. He was charged with causing malicious damage from fire and lighting a fire without authority. He was refused bail and will appear in Bowral Local Court today.

urn:contentItem:4MTY-VY60-TXDB-H2N1-00000-00Rain helps douse forest fire2007-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:34ZLexisNexisRain helps douse forest fire

Parts of the north-west received steady falls of rain overnight as heavy showers and isolated storms passed over the region.

Narrabri was inundated with about 38 millimetres, while Tamworth received 11mm.

The Rural Fire Service says the showers have helped dampen a 2,500 hectare blaze in the Pilliga State Forest south-west of Narrabri.

However, Inspector Steve Hall says there is a danger lightning strikes may have sparked new fires in the district.

"There was a fair amount of rain involved with the storm as it passed through and we certainly love to see the rain, we just don't like the lightning that comes with it unfortunately," he said.

urn:contentItem:5XYK-9P51-DYG0-9552-00000-00<published>2020-01-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Karen Sweeney<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - A man killed by a falling tree while battling a blaze in the state?s alpine region was a 40-year veteran firefighter.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Bill Slade, 60, was fighting fires with Parks Victoria at Omeo when he died on Saturday.<br/>   The married father of two from Wonthaggi has been remembered as one of the longest serving, most experienced and fittest firefighters.<br/>   ?This is a significant loss for the Forest Fire Management Victoria family and the community as a whole,? FFMV boss Chris Hardman said Sunday morning.<br/>   Mr Slade was on a taskforce working at the fire?s edge.<br/>   ?Although we do have enormous experience in identifying hazardous trees, sometimes these tree failures can?t be predicted,? Mr Hardman said.<br/>   ?It would have been a traumatic experience for everybody on that taskforce.?<br/>   Mr Slade had worked on major fire incidents in the past including the Ash Wednesday bushfires.<br/>   His 40 years service was recognised in a presentation in November.<br/>   Mr Slade?s death follows the death of fellow FFMV firefighter Mat Kavanagh, 43, who died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mr Hardman said despite the deaths firefighters would continue to be deployed.<br/>   ?We have to be out there ... it?s a long time before the risks around these fires are over,? he said.<br/>   They?ll be out in the field until late February or March, or possibly beyond.<br/>   ?I think we need to be really clear unless we get really significant rains ... 100-150mm of rain we?re going to be in this for the long haul,? he said.<br/>   Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp said ?benign conditions? are forecast in coming days, including thunderstorms expected to bring rain.<br/>   Victoria Police and Worksafe are investigating Mr Slade?s death.<br/>   While an emergency warning remains in place for a fire near Mount Hotham, the state of disaster declared for the regions has ended.<br/>   Milder conditions are forecast for the next week to 10 days, meaning attention can turn to getting the upper hand on the more than 20 fires still burning.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said relieving exhausted emergency services workers was also a priority.<br/>   "People are very fatigued, that is the case with communities but also the case with our emergency service personnel, they are very exhausted and we need to be able to rotate in and out people," she told reporters on Saturday.<br/>   "We have got a chance to do that whilst we are also still doing a lot of the planning, a lot of the work that we can do to try and minimise the future impact of these fires."<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYK-9P51-DYG0-9552-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="456"/><timeReceived>10:42 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty.
